titleStmt.title: Regional brain structure at the intersec�on of novelty-seeking trait and anxiety

analytic.title: Regional brain structure at the intersec�on of novelty-seeking trait and anxiety

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: The rela�onship between novelty-seeking and anxiety is complex. Individuals seeking new experiences (novelty-seeking bias) o�en navigate a delicate balance between curiosity and apprehension. An individual's tendency toward novelty-seeking may therefore be reflected in the substrates of these decision components and their interac�ons. In this study, we inves�gated grey mater (GM) structure associated with each of these contribu�ons. We applied both voxel-based (VBM) and source-based morphometry (SBM) to imaging data from 50 healthy par�cipants, looking, for the first �me, at the rela�onship between regional GM volume and novelty-seeking (Tridimensional Personality Ques�onnaire), anxiety (State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI), and their interac�on. On its own, novelty-seeking bias did not correlate with regional GM structure in either analysis. Trait anxiety correlated with increased subcallosal gyrus volume in the VBM analysis and was nega�vely associated with two components iden�fied in the SBM analysis, which mainly included temporal and frontal regions (i.e., le� inferior temporal gyrus, inferior frontal gyrus, middle temporal gyrus, le� middle frontal gyrus). Interac�on between novelty-seeking score and anxiety score, was expressed in GM volume within the le� inferior frontal gyrus (LIFG) in the VMB analysis. There was no suprathreshold interac�on with the components iden�fied using SBM. Together, this study provides new insight into the rela�onship between reward-related decisionmaking and anxiety. Within the le� inferior frontal gyrus, GM volume reflected the interac�on of novelty-seeking and anxiety, extending previous research that links lower le� inferior frontal gyral volume to reduced impulsivity with increased harm avoidance and anxiety. Our findings suggest this as a possible candidate region for pa�ent stra�fica�on and target for interven�on in anxiety. The novelty-seeking (NS) trait encompasses an inherent disposi�on to explore and inves�gate something new (Bunzeck and Düzel, 2006; Krebs et al., 2009). NS is linked to the increased tendency to ascribe reward to novel s�muli and is strongly associated with trait impulsivity (Acton, 2003; Evren

div.head: Introduc�on
div.p: regions (Van Schuerbeek et al. (2011). Other studies, however, report no overlap between these two dimensions (Gardini et al., 2009;Iidaka et al., 2006). Impulsivity and risk taking are also strongly linked to NS, so the expression of their interplay in brain structure likely mirrors the that inves�gated here. Indeed, cor�cal thickness of the ITG is reportedly higher in impulsive individuals (Schilling et al., 2012), while IFG GMV shows a nega�ve rela�onship with both impulsivity anxiety scores (Schaub et al., 2023). These observa�ons further support the case for a targeted inves�ga�on of the interac�on between NS and anxiety as expressed in regional differences in brain structure.

Voxel-based morphometry (VBM) (Ashburner and Friston, 2000) and Source Based Morphometry (SBM) (Saviola et al. (2020) can be used to quan�fy the rela�onship between grey mater (GM) and interindividual differences in NS and anxiety. VBM is an established method for comparing voxels throughout the brain and has been extensively applied to uncover anatomical differences that may underpin the expression of cogni�ve traits or pathological symptoms (Mechelli et al., 2005). The technique treats voxels (hence regions) independently and does not typically use informa�on about the rela�onship between different voxels, especially when they are not neighbouring in the brain.

However, anxiety likely involves a more distributed network of brain regions. This could poten�ally also be the case when inves�ga�ng the interac�on of anxiety and NS. Consequently, a mul�variate technique may be more effec�ve than a univariate alterna�ve at capturing anatomical differences related to these trait characteris�cs. Surface Based Morphometry (SBM) offers such a newer mul�variate approach that complements established univariate VBM methods. Here independent component analysis (ICA) technique is applied to iden�fy the sources of presented variability from all the GM scans and derive a subset of whole brain 'networks' showing cross-regional anatomical covaria�on. While VBM may be more sensi�ve to strongly localised regional differences, SBM can, in prac�ce, uncover more regional associa�ons as it bypasses mul�ple comparison issues inherent to the 'classical' univariate techniques. Correspondingly, a network of regions involved in trait anxiety has been iden�fied in one study using SBM (Saviola et al. (2020)). For these reasons, in the current study, both approaches were used to uncover the rela�onship between brain structure, trait anxiety and NS.

div.head: Aims and hypotheses
div.p: VBM and SBM analyses were thus undertaken to understand the neuroanatomical underpinnings, expressed in regional GMV, of NS, anxiety, and their interac�on.

The primary hypothesis is that trait NS will correlate with GMV within the prefrontal cortex, but the direc�onality in the area is not clear based on prior literature. Similarly, we hypothesised that anxiety would correlate with GMV in the IFG, ITG, amygdala and ACC. Lastly, we hypothesised that the neuroanatomical substrate for the interac�on between NS and anxiety, which has not been previously iden�fied, is likely to involve the IFG and/or the ITG.

div.head: Procedure and par�cipants
div.p: For this project, 52 right-handed, healthy par�cipants were recruited from 117 par�cipants that had completed an online study on novelty seeking behaviour (as part of a larger research project). These par�cipants were screened for lack of psychiatric or neurological disorder, no recent drug usage (past 2 months) and no excessive consump�on of alcohol (<10 glasses per week) or caffeine (<3 cups of coffee per day). They completed the novelty seeking dimension of the Tridimensional personality ques�onnaire (TPQ-NS) during an online session, and the state and trait anxiety ques�onnaire (STAI-S, STAI-T) in person, and subsequently underwent neuroimaging, during which a structural brain scan was acquired. These results form part of a larger research programme that also included a func�onal neuroimaging scan during a three-armed bandit task before and a�er the structural scan, as well as psychophysiological monitoring (full details in the supplementary material). Two par�cipants were excluded because of lower image quality (ra�o between weighted overall image quality and the mean z-score), resul�ng in 50 subjects (26 female, mean ± SD age = 22.7 ± 3.4 years).
Data was acquired using a 3T MRI scanner (Siemens), with a 64-channel radio-frequency head coil.

During the structural scan, a T1 weighted sequence was collected (TR = 2400ms, TE = 2.22ms, TI = 1000 ms, turbo factor = 256, slice thickness = 0.8 mm, volumes = 208). Addi�onally, 2 field maps (AP-PA) were acquired prior to the start of the func�onal scanning (TR = 8000ms, TE = 66ms, mul�-band accelera�on factor = 1, slice thickness = 2mm) with a �me dura�on of 0.08 sec. Slices were acquired to provide whole brain coverage in parallel orienta�on to the anterior-posterior commissural line.

Using CAT12 toolbox in SPM so�ware (Karl J. Friston, 2007), the grey mater (GM) from the anatomical scans was extracted and subjected to a volumetric brain morphometry (VBM) analysis. A�er the ini�al check of data quality (to avoid cri�cal ar�facts as head-mo�on effect, ghos�ng and stripes that could poten�ally affect the results), each image was reoriented according to the origin and then segmented in GM, white mater (WM) and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) with CAT12. Since our goal was to look for GM abnormali�es, only these images were used in our analysis. Image pre-processing followed established (default) se�ngs as per the manual of CAT 12 toolbox. In more detail, T1-weighted images were registered to MNI space and �ssue probability maps were used in affine registra�on and affine regulariza�on. The 'modulated normalized' se�ng was used which results in an analysis of rela�ve differences in regional GM volume which was subsequently corrected for the total intracranial volume (TIV) by global scaling. Subsequently, MRI inhomogenei�es and noise were removed, and intensi�es globally normalized. The sample homogeneity was visually inspected, and smoothing was undertaken using a 6 mm full width at half maximum of Gaussian smoothing kernel.

With the segmented, normalized and smoothed GM scans from the VBM pre-processing, we then u�lised the Group ICA of fMRI Toolbox (GIFT) (TReNDS, 2022) to perform SBM analysis. This toolbox uses Independent Component Analysis (ICA) technique to break the signal from all the GM scans to iden�fy the independent sources and isolate the presented variability in the dataset. The Infomax algorithm was used to maximize the recogni�on of the independent components (IC) (Lee et al., 1999) from the signal informa�on of the images and 20 IC were selected by default as the best op�on for low model order studies (Xu et al., 2009). The ICASSO analysis (Himberg and Hyvarinen, 2003) was selected to test for the reliability of the generated components with both RandInit and Bootstrap modes selected. ICA was run in 100 itera�ons with a minimum cluster size of 80. At comple�on of the analysis a mixing matrix was generated which contained loading coefficients for each par�cipant, demonstra�ng how each structural component contributed to the par�cipants' trait characteris�cs.

Seven components were selected to be reliable (as evaluated with the stability index (I q ) >0.85) and a parametric correla�on test was used to test for correla�ons of the trait characteris�cs to each of those components. All results were FDR corrected for mul�ple comparisons across the selected ICs similarly to other studies (Saviola et al., 2020) and the sta�s�cal analyses were performed via JASP so�ware (Team, 2023a).

div.head: Sta�s�cal analysis
div.p: At this point, we conducted sta�s�cal analyses to examine individual traits of anxiety and noveltyseeking temperament and their rela�onships to brain structure. For the VBM analysis, we used a mul�ple linear regression model that accounted for the total intracranial volume, with anxiety and novelty seeking as the covariates of interest. A�er ensuring the design's orthogonality, we conducted t-test comparisons to explore the posi�ve and nega�ve rela�onships between anxiety score, TPQ-NS score and their interac�on with GM volume. The anxiety was calculated by averaging between the trait and state dimensions of the STAI ques�onnaire due to their high correla�on. For the SBM, we performed a separate correla�on analysis between each anxiety dimension, novelty-seeking trait and the 7 reliable components iden�fied through the ICA. All results were false discovery rate (FDR) corrected to account for mul�ple comparisons and the sta�s�cal analysis were performed using JASP so�ware (Team, 2023b).

div.head: Demographics / Sample characterisa�on
div.p: Par�cipants' age, anxiety and novelty-seeking scores are presented in Table 1.

div.head: VBM results
div.p: The results from the VBM mul�ple regression analysis of GM are presented subsequently. All regions were ini�ally iden�fied using the Harvard-Oxford atlas and validated through inspec�on on high resolu�on anatomical scan (and reference to ? Mai et al…). The design orthogonality matrix did not illustrate any strong correla�on (r<0.3) between the parameters of interest or the global signal (corrected by TIV) (Appendix C).
Anxiety score positively correlates with anatomical differences in the grey matter of the left subcallosal cortex.

The STAI score correlated posi�vely with a small cluster located in the le� subcallosal cingulate gyrus area (MNI local maxima: x = -8, y = 21, z = -15, T-value = 5.57, p FWE-corr = 0.042) ( Figure 1). There were no significant clusters correla�ng nega�vely with the STAI score. Colour bar illustrates the T value.
Novelty-seeking did not correlate with any brain regions.
The TPQ-NS score lacked any posi�ve or nega�ve correla�ons at supratheshold significance with any brain regions (FWE correc�on at p<0.05).
Anxiety by novelty-seeking interaction correlated with the grey matter of the left Inferior Frontal Gyrus.
To test for neuroanatomical regions expressing the interac�on between anxiety and NS, the

div.head: SBM results
div.p: Trait anxiety negatively correlated with two components isolated from SBM.

Two components isolated from the SBM analysis were found to be significantly correlated with trait anxiety (p <0.05). Component 5 correlated nega�vely with the STAI-T scores of the par�cipants (rho = -0.43, p = 0.014) (Figure 3a). This component encompassed several brain regions including the le� supramarginal gyrus, the right temporal fusiform cortex, the le� middle frontal gyrus, the superior parietal lobule bilaterally and the middle temporal gyrus bilaterally (full list of brain regions present in Table 2). Component 8 also correlated nega�vely with the STAI-T score (rho= -0.375, p = 0.0245) ( Figure 3b) and involved the temporal fusiform cortex bilaterally (more pronounced on the le�), the right postcentral gyrus, the le� inferior temporal gyrus, the inferior frontal gyrus bilaterally, the right cingulate gyrus and the le� middle temporal gyrus (full list of brain regions present in Table 3). State anxiety, Novelty-seeking, and any interaction of novelty-seeking with anxiety did not correlate with any of the components isolated from SBM.
None of the isolated components showed a suprathreshold correla�on at criterion significance with the STAI-S score, the TPQ-NS score or the interac�on of STAI-S with TPQ-NS and STAI-T with TPQ-NS.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: This study inves�gated, within an 'analogue' sample of non-clinical individuals the structural anatomical differences, associated with trait and state anxiety characteris�cs in conjunc�on with novelty-seeking (NS) bias and their interac�on. The study focused on the GM using VBM and SBM as the techniques of choice.

div.head: Main findings
div.p: In this inves�ga�on, we hypothesized that NS seeking would be correlated primarily with GMV within prefrontal cor�cal areas. However, we observed no associa�on between NS and GMV either in the VBM or the SBM analysis surpassing stringent threshold significance. Previous studies present findings of a direct associa�on between NS and cor�cal structure, yet arguably these suffer from small and uneven sample sizes, wherein some inves�ga�ons pertain only to female (Van Schuerbeek et al., 2011) and others only to male par�cipants (Gardini et al., 2009). Addi�onally, many studies report differences in the absolute value of the NS score with our study. More specifically, one study of female par�cipants, NS correlated posi�vely with the volume of le� posterior cingulate and nega�vely with the volume of le� inferior frontal gyrus, the le� claustrum, le� culmen and the right cerebellar tonsil (Van Schuerbeek et al., 2011). There the mean NS score was notably higher than in this study (mean value of 22 ± 6 as opposed to 16 ± 5). Also, a separate study of a similar sample size to our present study (56 subjects) but with much lower mean NS score (10.4 ± 3.5), reports a posi�ve correla�on between NS with the le� middle frontal gyrus volume irrespec�ve to gender (Iidaka et al., 2006). A third study with similar NS scores as this one (17.9 ± 6.167) reports a posi�ve associa�on between NS and the le� thalamic pulvinar regions (Stam et al., 2018) but the sample size was confounded by inclusion of first degree rela�ves of pa�ents Hun�ngton disease and an uneven balance of male and female par�cipants. It is also worth no�ng that in the present study, our par�cipant exclusion criteria included drug usage, tobacco smoking and excessive alcohol consump�on, all factors that might increase novelty-seeking (Addicot et al., 2014;Wingo et al., 2016). Thus, the lack of findings here can be atributed to this factor as well, with the possibility that previous studies iden�fy novelty-seeking characteris�cs that are more atributable to comorbidi�es instead of the trait characteris�c. Arguably, our inves�ga�on might benefit from a larger sample size to uncover robust direct rela�onships between NS and neuroanatomical differences, given our more stringent inclusion criteria.

The SBM analysis similarly did not illustrate any direct associa�on between NS scores and neuroanatomical differences though, importantly, this is the first such SBM inves�ga�on of NS and GMV. Judging by the range different regions reported within the VBM literature (including studies using region-of-interest correc�on) (Laricchiuta et al., 2014;Petrosini et al., 2015) it is possible that this nega�ve finding in our SBM results could also be atributed to our smaller sample size.

Anxiety, on the other hand, showed a clearer rela�onship with neuroanatomical differences, including a posi�ve correla�on with a part of the le� subcallosal anterior cingulate cortex (iden�fied in the VBM analysis) and a nega�ve correla�on with mul�ple frontal, temporal, and limbic areas (iden�fied in the SBM analysis). These results corroborate and extend many previous studies on neuroanatomical differences associated with the expression of anxiety symptoms; the subcallosal area (subgenual cingulate) is implicated in fear memory (e.g. ex�nc�on of fearful cues), affec�ve experiences and regula�on of autonomic responses to stress (Palomero-Gallagher et al., 2015;Roth et al., 1988).

Ac�vity within this region reflects the presence of depressed mood and anhedonia and its volume is reduced in in major depressive disorder (Drevets et al., 2008), which is highly comorbid with anxiety (Knowles and Olatunji, 2020). While the subcallosal cluster iden�fied using VBM is small, a more distributed network of regions linked to trait anxiety was iden�fied by our mul�variate SBM analysis.
Prior studies have variously reported associa�ons between anxiety and func�onal or structural characteris�cs similar to our results from the SBM analysis. This has involved prefrontal regions (e.g.

inferior frontal gyrus (Li et al., 2019;Shang et al., 2014)), areas in temporal lobe (including the temporal fusiform gyrus (Liu et al., 2015;Pujol et al., 2009) and the middle temporal gyrus (Yun et al., 2017) as well as parietal areas (such as the supramarginal gyrus (Picó-Pérez et al., 2017), the superior parietal lobule (Wadden et al., 2018) and the postcentral gyrus (Li et al., 2019)). The SBM approach offers a fresh perspec�ve on the distributed interac�ons across the brain, contribu�ng to the expression of anxiety as a mul�dimensional trait that integrated perceptual, execu�ve, soma�c and mo�va�onal representa�ons. Saviola et al. (2020) performed the same SBM analysis inves�ga�ng the effects of trait and state anxiety as evaluated through the STAI ques�onnaire. Similarly, to this study, there was no effect of STAI-S anxiety on any of the iden�fied components. Areas such as the medial frontal gyrus, the supramarginal gyrus, medial temporal gyrus and the postcentral gyrus were all similarly modulated by trait anxiety. Nevertheless, in their results, STAI-T posi�vely correlated with cerebellar regions which were not iden�fied in our case. It is possible that the larger sample size of our study offers more generalisable results compared to the original study. The le� inferior temporal gyrus, which was nega�vely correlated with GM volume in this study, is increased in size in adolescents with generalised anxiety disorder (Strawn et al., 2013) and in social anxiety popula�on (Frick et al., 2013) but there are known anatomical varia�ons between those disorders and this could be atributed to using a ques�onnaire evalua�on of anxiety in healthy controls in our case.

Perhaps the most important result of this study was the iden�fica�on as a regional substrate suppor�ng interac�on between NS and anxiety, puta�vely media�ng the selec�on of mo�va�onal, behavioural responses that balance exploratory curiosity with cau�ous apprehension. This is the first study to our knowledge to show an interac�ve effect of anxiety and novelty-seeking on GMV. Previous VBM research links increased LIFG structure to lower levels of trait impulsivity (Schaub et al., 2023).

Similarly, a posi�ve associa�on is reported between LIFG volume and risk aversion measured behaviourally from performance of a risk-taking task (Nasiriavanaki et al., 2015). This is par�cularly relevant given the rela�onship between NS and impulsivity. NS is related to risk preference, where high NS traits are observed to correlate posi�vely with risk preference but nega�vely with risk predic�on (Wang et al., 2015). Moreover, in adolescents, greater NS appears associated with greater neural sensi�vity to risk and reward (Del Giacco et al., 2022). The LIFG is linked to pathologies associated with NS. Pa�ents with internet gambling disorder show hypoac�va�on of the LIFG in both execu�ve control and risky decision-making tasks (Zheng et al., 2019). Alcohol-dependent pa�ents also show atenuated LIFG reac�vity and reduced LIFG volume predict faster decision-making in a go-no go inhibi�on task (Wiers et al., 2015). Our findings extends this body of evidence for LIFG involvement in anxious apprehension, which could be conceptualised as a 'passive anxiety response' (where our results the reduced tendency to pursue something new when experiencing anxiousness) (Engels et al., 2007).

Interes�ngly, one fMRI study showed that LIFG ac�va�on is associated with increased risk-taking in low-anxiety par�cipants and greater avoidance of risk behaviour in individuals with high anxiety (Baker et al., 2022). However, contrary to findings of our (non-clinical) study, a large VBM meta-analysis of VBM data concluded that a reduced volume of this region is associated with the presence of anxiety disorders (Shang et al., 2014). Addi�onally, one VBM study of female par�cipants reported a nega�ve correla�on between LIFG GMV and both novelty-seeking and harm avoidance trait (highly correlated with an anxious endophenotype), characteris�cs (Van Schuerbeek et al., 2011). One possibility for these differences may be that the inves�ga�on here focused on healthy par�cipants. It is very likely that long term clinical anxiety has a differen�al influence in this region and what is captured here is an ini�al response of this region to anxiety that changes once anxiety becomes maladap�ve (or even that clinical anxiety in some way compensates for structural neuroanatomical features that may increase harm exposure). Moreover, it is possible that there are relevant fine-grained differences in the exact neuroanatomical loca�on since, even within our results, the SBM iden�fied anxiety-related IFG regions located superiorly to the LIFG region suppor�ng the interac�on of NS and anxiety.

Altogether, it is evident that this IFG region has a role in risk tasking, disinhibi�on, and anxiety. Our findings mo�vate the need for further inves�ga�ons, not least to explore the impact and value of targeted modula�on of this region func�on with brain s�mula�on techniques (e.g., transcranial ultrasound s�mula�on (Braun et al., 2020)) that could help uncover the causality. It is worth no�ng that we did not observe any rela�onship of GMV and a reduced anxiety with increased NS. This suggests a more complex or nuanced effect, though our sensi�vity may be constrained by a lack of findings rela�ng GMV to NS itself. A larger sample size might be needed to disentangle this rela�onship effec�vely.

div.head: Limita�ons
div.p: The results of this study should be considered considering several limita�ons. Firstly, the sample size in this study is rela�vely small and future studies should try to generalise these results with a larger dataset. This is par�cularly relevant given the differences in TPQ-NS scores between the different studies in ques�on (Stam et al., 2018;Van Schuerbeek et al., 2011), and a future study selec�ng par�cipants based on the ques�onnaire scores could be of interest. Addi�onally, while SBM uses different ways of valida�ng the reliability of the iden�fied components (Himberg and Hyvarinen, 2003), it is s�ll a data-driven technique, poten�ally requiring larger datasets to ensure even more reliable results. An added limita�on is that the TPQ-NS score was calculated on a different day to the scanning, but given the good test-retest reliability of the NS dimension (Waller et al., 1991), we do not expect this to impact the results in any significant way. In this study, also, the mul�ple regression model of the VBM analysis did not include age and gender which is typical for VBM studies. This had three reasons; firstly, age and gender would be correlated with the TPQ-NS score and thus impact the results, secondly the age range in this study was limited to young adults and, as such, would offer less variability in the dataset and lastly the inclusion of TIV accounted for larger brain size differences related to gender. Moreover, the cerebellum seems to be involved in both NS (Laricchiuta et al., 2014) and STAI (Saviola et al., 2020) anatomical differences and future analysis focusing on it, could be of interest. Lastly in this study, the focus was on GM due to prior suppor�ng research but there was no inves�ga�on of white mater, cor�cal surface or even res�ng-state func�onal imaging which could be inves�gated in the future.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this study, the TQP-NS did not show a robust correla�on with differences in GMV, contrary to predic�ons from previously published research, possibly due to our more stringent selec�on of par�cipants (excluding people with alcohol abuse, smoking, and illicit drug usage). This indicates the need for larger sample sizes and targeted selec�ons of par�cipants based on their NS scores in future studies. The structural brain correlates of anxiety, as quan�fied using the STAI ques�onnaire, on the other hand, extended previous findings illustra�ng the integra�ve involvement of specific temporal, frontal, and limbic regions. Most importantly, this study highlighted the role of the le� inferior frontal gyrus in suppor�ng the interac�on of NS and anxiety. This is a first inves�ga�on to our knowledge to make such a link and illustrates the importance of this region in mo�va�onal decision-making, with poten�al clinical relevance to pa�ent stra�fica�on and future targeted interven�ons.

-sta�s�c of a nega�ve effect of TPQ-NS score and posi�ve effect of STAI was regressed against whole brain voxel-wise GMV. This revealed a cluster located in the le� Inferior Frontal Gyrus (IFG) region within the inferior frontal sulcus (MNI local maxima: x = -42, y = 32, z = 16, T-value = 6.13, p FWE-corr = 0.008) (Figure 2).
